newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea to protect small firms from Hanbo crisis.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea to protect small firms from Hanbo crisis.

text.p: South Korea will supply 1.4 trillion won this year to stop Hanbo Steel Co's financial failure causing insolvencies of small and medium-sized firms, the Finance and Economy Ministry said on Monday.
The ministry said in a statement the government would also provide 700 billion won to banks for use to rediscount commercial bills issued by small and medium-sized firms.
The statement said the 700 billion won would be raised by issuing government bonds, while part of the 1.4 trillion won of funds would come from the central bank.
It did not give further details on fund-raising.
The failure of Hanbo Steel, the nation's second largest steelmaker, has made it hard for small and medium-sized firms to get bank loans or have their commercial bills discounted.
The steel firm, flagship unit of the nation's 14th largest conglomerate Hanbo Group, was declared insolvent on January 23.
Pohang Iron and Steel Co last week accepted a request from creditor banks to help run the troubled steelmaker, which is now seeking court receivership.

The statement also said the government would release 561.8 billion won, allocated for various aid programmes to support small and medium-sized companies, in February. The release was originally scheduled for the first half of this year.
In the manufacturing sector, companies with 300 employees or less are classified as medium-sized while those with 50 employees or less small firms.
